data.text:
Fellow Svengoolie SvenPals everywhere will be jumping for joy for his big broadcast of a classic mammoth Richard Gordon/Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) sci-fi masterpiece.

â€œSvengoolieâ€ presents his big broadcast of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958), plus â€œSventoonieâ€

The legendary Berwyn/Chicago-based classic mammoth sci-fi feature film masterpiece host will present his big broadcast of â€œFiend Without A Faceâ€ (1958), this Sat.; Nov. 19 at 8 p.m. Eastern/7 p.m. Central on Me-TV.

The 1958 classic sci-fi/creature masterpiece production was directed by veteran British cinematographer-turned-film and television director Arthur Crabtree*. Some of Crabtreeâ€™s* best known productions throughout his film and television career include directing his Rank/Gainsborough drama production of â€œThey Were Sistersâ€ (1945) with Phyllis Calvert, James Mason, Hugh Sinclair and Pamela Mason and his Rank/Triton production of â€œDonâ€™t Ever Leave Meâ€ (1949) with Jimmy Hanley, Linden Travers and young Petula Clark; long before Clark rose to greater fame in the mid-1960s for her classic mammoth pop music recordings in Britain and the United States. Crabtree* also directed episodes of the classic mammoth British television mystery masterpiece series with Boris Karloff, â€œColonel March of Scotland Yardâ€ (Crabtree worked on the series from 1955-56, â€œColonel March of Scotland Yardâ€ was syndicated for local television stations in the United States by Official Films); according to additional details from IMDB. The same year that he worked on his classic mammoth sci-fi/creature masterpiece feature of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) Crabtree also worked on 12 episodes of the classic Columbia Pictures/Screen Gems syndicated television masterpiece adaptation of Sir Walter Scottâ€™s novel of Wilfred of Ivanhoe, â€œIvanhoeâ€ in 1958 with young Roger Moore in the title role.

One year after â€œFiend Without A Face,â€ Crabtree directed the classic mammoth British â€œHypnovistaâ€ horror-mystery masterpiece with young Michael Gough, â€œHorrors of the Black Museumâ€ (1959, released theatrically in Great Britain by Nat Cohen and Stuart Levy; released in the United States by Samuel Z. Arkoff and James H. Nicholsonâ€™s American-International Pictures; which began a long-term production and distribution pact of the producersâ€™ productions between Arkoff, Cohen, Levy and Nicholson within Britian and the United States).

Veteran producer/distributor Richard Gordon served as executive producer of Crabtreeâ€™s* production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958). Gordon also helped veteran horror legend Bela Lugosi return to the United States after the abrupt ending of his 1951 British stage tour of Hamilton Deaneâ€˜s stage adaptation of Bram Stokerâ€˜s â€œDraculaâ€ by encouraging Lugosi to appear John Gillingâ€˜s production of â€œVampire Over Londonâ€ (released in Britain in 1952, released by Columbia Pictures in the United States under the title of â€œMy Son, The Vampireâ€ in 1963 to capitalize on Allan Shermanâ€˜s title 1963 spook comedy recording that was released on the record label of rival studio Warner Bros.); which was an entry in the â€œOld Mother Rileyâ€ comedy film series with Arthur Lucan for Britainâ€™s Renown Pictures (Renown was known as the production company that co-produced Brian Desmond Hurstâ€˜s classic mammoth 1952 Holiday feature film masterpiece adaptation of Charles Dickensâ€˜ â€œA Christmas Carol/Scroogeâ€ with Alastair Sim), according to IMDB. Gordon later served as executive producer of Lindsay Shonteffâ€™s cult classic thriller feature masterpiece production of â€œDevil Dollâ€ (1964) with Bryant Haliday (who was one of the original co-founders of art-house producer/distribution firm Janus Films, the company behind The Criterion Collection line of critically-acclaimed feature films from Janus and productions leased from other studios/production firms for Blu-Ray, DVD and select streaming ), Yvonne Romain, William Sylvester and the vocal stylings of Sadie Corre. The Gordon-Crabtree* production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) was produced under the moniker of Amalgamated Productions.

Veteran producer John Croydon also co-produced the 1958 Gordon-Crabtree* production of â€œFiend Without a Face.â€ Croydon later served as the producer Ian Curteisâ€™s classic sci-fi/horror masterpiece production with Mary Peach and Norman Wooland, â€œThe Projected Manâ€ (1966, released in the United States by Universal Studios in 1967). Veteran producer/screenwriter Ronald Kinnoch served as co-producer and veteran/producer screenwriter Charles F. Vetter also served in an uncredited role an executive producer in the Gordon/Crabtree* production of â€œFiend Without a Face.â€ Both Kinnoch and Vetter previously co-wrote the screenplay for the cult classic Gordon/Shonteff thriller masterpiece production of â€œDevil Dollâ€ (1964) with veteran author Frederick Escreet Smith (Kinnoch received credit under the pseudonym of George Barclay for the 1964 production of â€œDevil Doll,â€ Lance Z. Hargreaves received credit under the pseudonym of Lance Z. Hargreaves for the 1964 production of â€œDevil Dollâ€).

Kinnoch/Barclay previously produced Wolf Rillaâ€™s classic Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) sci-fi/horror/thriller masterpiece with George Sanders, Barbara Shelley, Michael Gwynn and Martin Stephens; â€œVillage of the Damnedâ€ (1960, adapted from John Wyndham/John Harrisâ€™ novel, â€œThe Midwich Cuckoos;â€ Kinnoch/Barclay co-wrote the screenplay adaptation of â€œVillage of the Damnedâ€ with veteran screenwriter Stirling Silliphant). Charles F. Vetter previously produced Robert Dayâ€™s classic Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) British sci-fi masterpiece production of â€œFirst Man Into Spaceâ€ (1959, with Marshall Thompson, Marla Landi and Bill Edwards).

The screenplay for the Gordon/Crabtree* cult classic sci-fi/creature masterpiece production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) was written by veteran screenwriter Herbert J. Leder.

â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) was released theatrically throughout Great Britain via Eros Films Ltd., the company was founded by Phil and Sid Hyams; according to IMDB. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) handled the North American theatrical distribution/releasing rights to â€œFiend Without a Face.â€ Complete theatrical re-issue, television syndication and home entertainment licensing rights to â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) would later revert to Richard Gordonâ€™s Gordon Films, Inc. (under the estate of Richard Gordon since Gordonâ€™s death in 2011); according to veteran film distributor Kit Parkerâ€™s retrospective on veteran film producer Gordon.

This will mark Svenâ€™s second big broadcast of the classic mammoth Crabtree*-Gordon-MGM 1958 sci-fi masterpiece production on the airlanes of Me-TV. A classic mammoth sci-fi feature film masterpiece that Sven wanted to show on his big broadcast showcase for many years, he finally got the chance to showcase â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) as a Sven big broadcast premiere on Me-TV back in May 2021.

Who was in the Richard Gordon-Arthur Crabtree* classic sci-fi/horror masterpiece production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958)?

The players who appeared in the classic mammoth 1958 Richard Gordon/MGM sci-fi masterpiece production of â€œFiend Without a Fcaeâ€ were Marshall Thompson (as Maj. Cummings), Kim Parker (as Barbara Griselle), Stanley Maxted (as Col. Butler), Kynaston Reeves (as Prof. R.E. Walgate), Terence â€œTerryâ€ Kilburn (as Capt. Al Chester), James Dyrenforth (as the Mayor), Robert MacKenzie (as Constable Gibbons), Peter Madden (as Dr. Bradley), Gil Winfield (as Dr. Warren), Michael Balfour (as Sgt. Kasper), Lala Lloyd (as Amelia Adams), Shane Cordell (as a Nurse), Launce Maraschal (as Melville), E. Kerrigan Prescott (as an Atomic Engineer) and R. Meadows White (as Ben Adams).

Marshall Thompson previously appeared in the role of Tom Markel in Francis D. Lyonâ€™s classic mammoth Universal Studios creature fantasy/thriller feature film masterpiece production with Faith Domergue, Richard Long, Kathleen Hughes, David Janssen (later of TVâ€™s â€œThe Fugitiveâ€ and â€œHarry Oâ€ fame), Jack Kelly and Olan Soule; â€œCult of the Cobraâ€ (1955) and also appeared in the role of Johnson in Jesse Hibbsâ€˜ classic mammoth Universal biopic-war drama masterpiece adaptation of Audie Murphyâ€˜s autobiography, â€œTo Hell and Backâ€ (1955) with Murphy, Janssen, Charles Drake, Jack Kelly, Paul Picerni, Gregg Palmer, Susan Kohner and Denver Pyle (later known for his guest appearances on â€œThe Andy Griffith Showâ€ and of â€œThe Dukes of Hazzardâ€ fame). The same year that he appeared in â€œFiend Without a Face,â€ Thompson played the role of Col. Edward Carruthers in Edward L. Cahnâ€™s classic mammoth United Artists sci-fi creature masterpiece with Shirley Patterson, Kim Spalding, Richard Benedict and veteran stunt performer Ray â€œCrashâ€ Corrigan; â€œIt! The Terror Beyond Spaceâ€ (1958). Aside from her numerous acting appearances in her brief acting career and two years before Fiend Without a Face,â€ Kim Parker previously appeared in the role of one of the fire maidens in Cy Rothâ€™s cult classic sci-fi masterpiece with Maya Koumani, Norma Arnould, Sylvia Burrows, Marcella Georgius, Corinne Gray, Richard Walter, Susan Shaw and Anthony Dexter; â€œFire Maidens of Outer Spaceâ€ (1956) and previously appeared in the role of Suzanne in Charles Saunders and W. Lee Wilderâ€˜s cult classic sci-fi production of â€œThe Man Without a Bodyâ€ (1957), one year before the production of â€œFiend Without a Face.â€

In addition to his numerous British film and television screen appearance roles throughout his career, Peter Madden also aappeared in the role of Mc Adams in Terence Youngâ€˜s classic mammoth Eon Productions-United Artists â€œJames Bond/007â€ secret agent action-adventure feature film masterpiece adaptation of Ian Flemingâ€˜s â€œFrom Russia With Loveâ€ (1963) with Sean Connery, Robert Shaw, Bernard Lee, Eunice Gayson and Daniela Bianchi and in an uncredited role as the undertaker in the opening sequence to the classic mammoth Patrick McGoohan-ITC sci-fi/mystery/fantasy series, â€œThe Prisonerâ€ (1967-68) and later appeared in the role of the coach driver in Terence Fisherâ€˜s classic mammoth Hammer Films-Paramount Pictures horror feature film masterpiece production of â€œFrankenstein and the Monster from Hellâ€ (1974) with Peter Cushing, Madeline Smith, a post-â€œDoctor Whoâ€ Patrick Troughton, a pre-â€œStar Warsâ€ David Prowse, Shane Briant and Nicholas Smith of BBC televisionâ€™s â€œAre You Being Served?â€ fame. Alongside his numerous acting appearances in Britain and the same year that he appeared in â€œFiend Without a Face,â€ James Dryenforth was best remembered for his role of Col. Archibald Gracie in Roy Ward Bakerâ€˜s classic critically-acclaimed mammoth Rank Organisation historical drama masterpiece adaptation of Walter Lordâ€˜s novel of the 1912 sinking of the Titanic, â€œA Night to Rememberâ€ (1958) with Kenneth More, Honor Blackman, Robert Ayres, Ronald Allen, Harriette Johns, young David McCallum (later of TVâ€™s â€œThe Man from U.N.C.L.E.â€ & â€œNCISâ€ fame), Laurence Naismith, Jane Downs and Michael Goodliffe.

Earlier in his acting career, Terry Kilburn was best known for his role of Tiny Tim in Edward L. Marinâ€™s classic mammoth Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) holiday drama masterpiece adaptation of Charles Dickensâ€™ â€œA Christmas Carolâ€ (1938) with Reginald Owen, Gene Lockhart, Kathleen Lockhart, Ann Rutherford and young Leo G. Carroll; in the role of John Colley in Sam Wood and Sidney Franklinâ€˜s classic mammoth MGM drama masterpiece adaptation of James Hiltonâ€˜s â€œGoodbye, Mr. Chipsâ€ (1939) with Robert Donat, Greer Garson and young Paul Henreid (credited as Paul von Henried) and in the role of Plaster in W.S. Van Dykeâ€˜s classic mammoth MGM â€œAndy Hardyâ€ family comedy masterpiece installment of â€œAndy Hardy Gets Spring Feverâ€ (1939) with Mickey Rooney, Ann Rutherford, Lewis Stone, Fay Holden, Cecilia Parker, Sara Haden and Helen Gilbert.

Inspiration for â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958):

For the trademark â€œcreatureâ€ in the classic mammoth 1958 Crabtree/Gordon/MGM sci-fi masterpiece production of â€œFiend Without a Face;â€ it was reported that the screenplay for Lederâ€™s screenplay was adapted from an original short story by veteran author Amelia Reynolds Long. Longâ€™s original story was titled â€œThe Thought Monsterâ€ and was written in 1930, which was 28 years before the production of â€œFiend Without a Face;â€ according to Michael Atkinsonâ€™s Oct. 2009 passage for Janus Filmsâ€™ Criterion Collection line of several classic sci-fi feature film masterpieces titled â€œTales from the Criterion â€˜Cryptâ€™;â€ â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ is one in a handful of select classic mammoth sci-fi feature film masterpiece productions handled by Janus/Criterion for DVD disc and streaming distribution by arrangement with Gordon Films/the estate of Richard Gordon.

Richard Crabtree* and his reluctance in directing â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958)

According to IMDBâ€™s trivia section on the classic mammoth 1958 Richard Gordon sci-fi masterpiece production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958); it was reported that Richard Crabtree* was reluctant in directing the aforementioned production for Gordonâ€™s production firm. Marshall Thompson recounted that Crabtree* was not fond of the science fiction/sci-fi genre for feature films, the veteran director felt that it was a step back from his traditional feature film â€œhouse styleâ€ genres of dramas, mysteries, biopics and light comedies at the time.

It was reported that Crabtree* could barely hold himself throughout the overall production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ and decided to walk off on the set. The classic mammoth 1958 Gordon sci-fi feature film masterpiece was almost an unfinished production until Thompson decided to serve in an uncredited additional position as director- to complete the scenes that Crabtree* refused to work on. Because of Thompsonâ€™s decision, the production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ was completed on schedule.

Reactions back and forth across the pond for the original British and U.S. theatrical releases of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958)

During the original British theatrical release of the Crabtree*-Gordon production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958), it was reported that several audience members at the Ritz Theater in Leicester Square (todayâ€™s Cineworld Cinema at Leicester Square) in London, England were shocked at several moments in the classic mammoth 1958 sci-fi masterpiece production. The film received the British Film Classification seal of â€œCertificate X;â€ according to additional details from IMDBâ€™s trivia section.

It was also reported that for the original New York City showing of the MGM theatrical release of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) at the now-defunct Rialto Theatre had a â€œsidewalk promotional gimmick stunt for the U.S. theatrical release. Underneath the front entrance marquee at the Rialto, a mock display was constructed for interested theatergoers with a prop â€œcreatureâ€ figurine that resembled the creature in the 1958 production and was controlled with a motor with recorded sound effects in the display. It was mentioned that the size of the interested theatergoers who saw the mock â€œcreatureâ€ display increased significantly and caused significant delays in both pedestrian and automobile traffic. Because of the increased size of the crowd on both the sidewalk and the street, New York City Police ordered that the Rialto management remove the â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ display, in terms of public safety.

â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958): Part of MGM and Richard Gordonâ€™s original double-feature theatrical release in the United States and additional promotional gimmicks

According to an original 1958 MGM exhibitorsâ€™ leaflet for the Richard Gordon double-feature presentation in the United States, â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ was paired with the Richard Gordon-Robert Day classic mammoth mystery/horror masterpiece production of â€œThe Haunted Stranglerâ€ (1958) with silver screen horror legend Boris Karloff, along with Elizabeth Allan, Anthony Dawson, Jean Kent, Vera Day, Tim Turner, Diane Aubrey, Dorothy Gordon and Leslie Perrins.

According to Bruce Kawinâ€™s 2001 essay for the Janus Films/Criterion Collection DVD release of the Crabtree*-Gordon production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958); it was mentioned that the brief MGM theatrical release was hugely popular with teenage audiences at the time.

Alongside the aforementioned New York/Rialto promotional stunt for â€œFiend Without a Face,â€ MGM management encouraged participating theaters from coast-to-coast to have numerous promotional gimmicks for the original 1958 double-feature theatrical release. According to a rare, original 1958 MGM exhibitorsâ€™ booklet for the Richard Gordon double-feature presentation of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ and â€œThe Haunted Stranglerâ€ that was unearthed on the classic mammoth sci-fi/horror feature film masterpiece appreciation site, From Zombos Closet; a â€œmask contestâ€ was suggested to participating theaters. For â€œFiend Without a Face;â€ young artists from coast-to-coast were encouraged to create the scariest â€œmaskâ€ that was inspired by original MGM poster art and lobby cards for the production. It was mentioned that theater managers from coast-to-coast were encouraged to have a â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ mask show contest for the participants during a Saturday afternoon matinee screening of the double-feature release of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ and â€œThe Haunted Strangler.â€ The participating contestant who got the biggest applause for their â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ mask art creation would win a prize as part of a promotional tie-in with local toy stores and/or local department stores.

Richard Gordonâ€™s proposed sequel for â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€

According to additional details from IMDBâ€™s trivia section, it was reported that Richard Gordon had planned on doing a sequel to â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ with director Norman J. Warren 1990, with a mix of stop-motion animation and CGI effects for the trademark â€œcreatures.â€ The plans for Gordon and Warrenâ€™s sequel never materialized due to a lack of funding.

Be sure to watch Svengoolieâ€™s big broadcasts of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958), plus â€œSventoonie;â€ this Sat. on Me-TV!

With Marshall Thompson. Kim Parker, Kynaston Reeves, Stanley Maxted, Terence â€œTerryâ€ Kilburn, James Dyrenforth, Robert MacKenzie, Peter Madden, Gil Winfield, Michael Balfour, Lala Lloyd, Shane Cordell, Launce Maraschal, E. Kerrigan Prescott and R. Meadows White; you will not want to miss out on Svengoolieâ€™s big broadcast of the classic mammoth Richard Gordon-Arthur Crabtree*-MGM sci-fi creature masterpiece feature production of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) olus â€œSventoonie;â€ this Sat. on Me-TV! A wonderful treat ofor all fellow super SvenPals and fellow super classic sci-fi aficionados everywhere with Svenâ€™s fun facts, maestro Sven and maestro Doug Gravesâ€™ parody song, Sven and Kerwynâ€™s â€œmail callâ€ segment, â€œSventoonieâ€ and much, much more! You will not be disappointed! Highly recommended to all fellow super SvenPals and all fellow super classic mammoth sci-fi feature film masterpiece aficionados everywhere!

I missed all my fellow Super SvenPals/Super Tooners for the Live-Tweeting of Sven & â€œX: The Man With the X-Ray Eyesâ€ and Sventoonieâ€™s tribute to â€œBrother from Another Planetâ€ (1984), I am happy to be back in the Live-Tweeting airlanes with all my fellow Super SvenPals/Super Tooners and I am looking forward to Live-Tweeting Sven/â€Fiend Without a Faceâ€ & Sventoonieâ€™s tribute to Roger Cormanâ€™s â€œLittle Shop of Horrors;â€ this Sat. on Me-TV! -C.H.

*Sidebar: Arthur Crabtree is not connected to the character of Officer Crabtree, played by Arthur Bostrom on the long-running classic BBC television wartime-themed comedy/farce/satire series, â€œAllo, Allo!â€ (Bostrom appeared in the role of Officer Crabtree in the series from 1985-92). Fun Fact: Along with Svenâ€™s classic â€œHit the Theme for Us, Chasâ€ sound bite phrase, I also used a sound bite of Arthur Bostromâ€™s famous opening phrase for his â€œOfficer Crabtreeâ€ character from â€œAllo, Allo!â€ for the opening of my 2016-17 weekly Hood College online radio series, â€œYours Truly, Chris Hamby!â€ â€“C.H.

This weekâ€™s edition of â€œSilver Screen Reflectionsâ€ is dedicated to the memory of two legends that we lost recently, including legendary actor/artist/singer and lecturer Robert Clary (1926-2022) of TVâ€™s â€œHoganâ€™s Heroesâ€ fame & legendary actor/animated voice-over artist Kevin Conroy (1955-2022) of TVâ€™s â€œBatman: The Animated Seriesâ€ fame. #RIPLegends.

Svengoolie presents his big broadcast of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958), plus â€œSventoonieâ€

Sat., Nov. 19 at 8 p.m. Eastern/7 p.m. Central on Me-TV

To all fellow Super Svengoolie SvenPals/fellow Super â€œToon In With Meâ€ Tooners/fellow Super readers/fellow subscribers of â€œSilver Screen Reflectionsâ€ everywhere: Seriously, Please, please be good, kind, courteous, safe and respectful to each other. Letâ€™s all look to positive/uplifting enlightenment, wisdom and encouragement from Svengoolie, all fellow super Svengoolie SvenPals everywhere, all fellow super Me-TV â€œToon In With Meâ€/â€Saturday Morning Cartoonsâ€ Tooners, all fellow super Mystery Science Theater 3000/MST3K MSTies everywhere and all fellow super classic film/television aficionados everywhere. Again, to all fellow super Svengoolie SvenPals and all fellow super Me-TV â€œToon In With Meâ€/â€Saturday Morning Cartoonsâ€ Tooners, fellow super MST3K MSTies & fellow super classic film & TV aficionados everywhere; safety first, to our fellow super SvenPals/MSTies/Tooners who have not made a plan to get their vaccines yet, be sure to schedule your vaccines & booster vaccines by contacting your doctor/physician/healthcare professional soon, follow all precautions safely and seriously, wear a protective face mask/appropriate protective face covering, wash your hands for approximately 20 sec., avoid touching your face, practice proper social distancing/physical distancing protocols, use a tissue/sleeve when coughing/sneezing, stay home, keep healthy and stay well. Again, letâ€™s all take preventative measures/steps by being safe, keeping healthy and staying well- and again, we fellow Super SvenPals everywhere highly recommend watching Kerwynâ€™s informative coronavirus/COVID-19 prevention safety public service announcement! Escape from anxiety, chaos and stress by relaxing and having fun with Sven and his Sat. evening big broadcasts of classic creature/sci-fi/monster/horror/fantasy feature film masterpieces on Me-TVâ€™s big broadcast airlanes featuring Svenâ€™s big broadcasts of his big Me-TV broadcast of â€œFiend Without a Faceâ€ (1958) and â€œSventoonie!â€ Join in on the fun with all fellow super SvenPals everywhere by live-tweeting on the Twitter airlanes during Svenâ€™s Sat. evening big broadcasts and.or Toony & Billâ€™s â€œToon In With Me!â€ Again, be good, safety first, keep healthy and stay well, Sven/Rich Koz, the entire Sven/Sventoonie/â€Toon Inâ€/Me-TV production team & the entire crowd of fellow super Svengoolie SvenPals everywhere! To quote Svengoolieâ€™s executive producer, Jim Roche: â€œ#KeepCalmAndWatchSven!â€ â€“C.H.

Extra! Extra! Extra! Cameo Credit to fellow Super Svengoolie SvenPal/Super â€œToon In With Meâ€ Tooner/Super broadcaster/Super DJ Sarah Rhodes/Sarahgoolie for mentioning this on the airlanes! On Sunday afternoon, Nov. 20 at 3:30 p.m. Eastern/2:30 p.m. Central on most Me-TV stations and just in time for the upcoming Thanksgiving/Turkey Day Holiday, the classic episode of â€œWKRP In Cincinnati,â€ â€œTurkeys Awayâ€ will be shown as part of Me-TVâ€™s â€œA Very Merry Me-TVâ€ Sunday showcase! Be sure to play Creedence Clearwater Revivalâ€™s classic mammoth 1969 Fantasy Records rock masterpiece from CCRâ€™s â€œWillie and the Poor Boysâ€ album, â€œIt Came From the Skyâ€ after Johnny Fever (Howard Hessemanâ€™s) comment about the Pinedale Shopping Center after Les Nessman (Richard Sanders)â€™s â€œTurkey Dayâ€ aftermath! -C.H.

Extra! Extra! Extra! In commemoration of the centennial of the birth of â€œPeanutsâ€ creator/cartoonist Charles M. Schulz (Nov. 26, 1922-Feb. 12, 2000); Me-TV will be showcasing two big broadcast premieres of two classic mammoth Charlie Brown/Peanuts feature-length animated theatrical film masterpieces that were co-produced by Schultz, Bill Melendez and CBSâ€™ theatrical film unit (then-under the â€œCinema Center Filmsâ€ moniker), beginning with â€œA Boy Named Charlie Brownâ€ (1969) this Sun. evening, Nov. 20 at 8 p.m. Eastern/7 p.m. Central, plus â€œSnoopy, Come Homeâ€ (1972) on Sun. evening, Nov. 27 at 8 p.m. Eastern/7 p.m. Central!

Sidebar: Because the Peanuts animated TV specials (â€œItâ€™s The Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown,â€ â€œA Charlie Brown Thanksgiving,â€ â€œA Charlie Brown Christmas,â€ etc.) were on the CBS television network at the time of the original theatrical releases of â€œA Boy Named Charlie Brownâ€ and â€œSnoopy Come Homeâ€ (the Peanuts animated TV specials aired on CBS until 2000), that is how CBS co-produced the first two â€œPeanutsâ€ animated theatrical films with Schulz and Melendez in 1969 and 1972. CBS/Paramount Global (the former ViacomCBS) still owns the theatrical re-issue (via Paramount Pictures), TV syndication (via CBS Studios/CBS Media Ventures) and home entertainment/streaming rights (via CBS Home Entertainment/Paramount Home Entertainment) to the two aforementioned full-length â€œPeanutsâ€ animated feature films from 1969 and 1972, according to IMDB. -C.H.

Because of a controversial & corrupt Schnook/Wackadoodle billionaireâ€™s recent purchase of Twitter and his corrupt/controversial plans for the social media site- many fellow Super SvenPals/Super Tooners are wondering about the future of our Live-Tweeting sessions for Sven/â€Toon Inâ€/Sventoonie, etc. Hereâ€™s what you should do in the event if Twitter has major =problems:

To fellow Super SvenPals/Super Tooners who have not done this yet: I highly recommend subscribing to my â€œSilver Screen Reflectionsâ€ weekly Sven film blog site by pressing the â€œsubscribeâ€ button at the very top of my â€œSilver Screen Reflectionsâ€ blog site page! Besides bookmarking this site, be sure to enter your E-Mail address and press â€œsubscribe!â€ And if youâ€™re on WordPressâ€™ platform, feel free to follow â€œSilver Screen Reflections!â€ Again, I highly appreciate all my fellow Super SvenPals/Super Tooners who have subscribed to my weekly â€œSilver Screen Reflectionsâ€ Sven film blog! -C.H.

Donâ€™t Delay, Subscribe to â€œSilver Screen Reflectionsâ€ today!

And because of ongoing Twitter tech. problems: In case my posts for â€œ#Svengoolie,â€ â€œ#ToonInWithMeâ€ and/or â€œ#Sventoonie;â€ including the return of the â€œ#ChrisHambyPhotoGalleryâ€ in the Late-Late Thurs./early Fri. morning timeframe along with reply/response tweets to fellow Super SvenPals/Super Tooners do not appear in the aforementioned Twitter feeds and/or Twitter notification feeds, hereâ€™s what to do:

Go to my Twitter page, â€œchrishambyfilms.â€

Click on the â€œmedia tab.â€

â€œChrisHambySvenâ€ will still be used as a back-up site. -C.H.

Be sure to watch Toony & Billâ€™s â€œToon In With Meâ€ big broadcasts weekday mornings at 7 a.m. Eastern/6 a.m. Central on the airlanes of Me-TV! And be sure to watch Sventoonieâ€™s big tribute to Roger Cormanâ€™s â€œThe Little Shop of Horrorsâ€ this Sat., Nov. 19 after â€œSventoonieâ€ on Me-TV! And Good News, I will join you all on Thurs. morning for Toony & Billâ€™s â€œToon In With Meâ€ parody big broadcast & I hope all my airlanes will be completely there! -C.H.

Extra! Extra! Extra! After a long, long search since the Fall 2022 edition of â€œScary Monstersâ€ was unavailable for purchase anywhere within my home area of Frederick, I finally received the â€œScary Monsters Fall 2022/#128â€ edition featuring Svengoolie/Rich Kozâ€™s article and much, much more! And officially in the â€œHamby Film Vault!â€ â€œScary Monsters #128â€ is still available for purchase via the official Scary Monsters/MyMovieMonsters.com site!

Extra! Extra! Extra! And again, if you havenâ€™t done so- be sure to enter your â€œSpawn of Svengoolieâ€ Sven video submission via the official new Svengoolie smartphone app from Me-TV! Many fellow Super SvenPals/Super Tooners have entered! Donâ€™t delay, enter today! -C.H.
